81.text: Ahura-Mazda said to the hallowed Zarathustra: “I created, most holy Zarathustra, into a delicious spot what was hitherto wholly uninhabitable. For had not I, most holy Zarathustra, converted into a delicious spot what was hitherto wholly uninhabitable, all earthly life would have been poured forth after Airyaua-vaêjô.*

82.text: [“Into a charming region (I converted) one which did not enjoy prosperity, the second (region) into the first; in opposition to it is great destruction of the existing cultivation.”] †

83.text: As the first best of regions and countries, I, who am Ahura-Mazda, created Airyana-vaèjo of good capability ; thereupon in opposition to him Angrô-mainyus, the death-dealing, created a mighty serpent and snow, the work of the Daevas.‡

94.text: [“And he (Angrô-mainyus) is endowed with various powers and various forma. Wherever these come, on being invoked by one devoted to Yâtu, there the most horrible Yâtu sins arise ; then spring up those which tend to murder and the deadening of the heart ; powerful are they by dint of concealing their hideouaness and by their enchanted potions.”]

Thereupon Angrô-mainyus, the death-dealing, created in opposition to him irregularly recurring evils (sicknesses)‡ and un-Arian plagues of the country.§

264.text: He has confessed what he has done amiss in thoughts words, and deeds.

265.text: He has atoned for what he has done amiss in thoughts, words, and deeds.

266.text: Whoso slays one of those dogs which belong to the cattle or the clan, or one of the blood-hounds which are trained ;

267.text: His soul departs exciting abhorrence and sick from this our (world) to that above the earth.

268.text: (She is) like a wolf in a great wood, who is able to wound.

269.text: No other departed soul will keep company with her, for she is horrible and miserable ;

270.text: Nor do the dogs like her, who take care and protect the bridge (Chinvat) because she is horrible and detestable.4

271.text: Whoso wounds a dog which belongs to the cattle ;

272.text: Or cuts off his ears or his feet;

273.text: If then a thief or a wolf comes to those folds * and carries off property without (any) one being aware of it ;

274.text: Then shall he make good the loss,

275.text: Let him atone for the wound of the dog with the punishment of the Baŏdhô-varsta.

276.text: Whoso inflicts a wound on a dog which belongs to the Tillage ;

277.text: Who cuts off his ears or his feet :

278.text: If then a thief or a wolf comes to this village and carries off property without their being aware of it ;

279.text: Then shall he make good the loss.

280.text: Let him atone for the wound of the dog with the punishment of the Baŏdhô-varsta.

281.text: Creator! He who inflicts a dangerous wound on a dog belonging to the cattle, which impairs his vital powers ;

283.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda: Letthem strikeeight hundred blows with the horse-goad,eight hundred with the Çraŏshô-charana.

284.text: Creator ! He who inflicts a dangerous wound on a dog belonging to a village, which impairs his vital powers ;

285.text: What is the punishmentt for it?

286.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : Strike seven hundred strokes with the horse-goad, seven hundred with the Çraŏshô-charana.

287.text: Creator ! He who inflicts a dangerous wound on a bloodhound, which impairs his vital powers ;

288.text: What is the punishment for it?

289.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : Strike six hundred blows with the horse-goad, six hundred with the Çraŏshô-charana.

290.text: Creator ! He who inflicts a dangerous wound on a young dog, which impairs his vital powers ;

291.text: What is the punishment for it ?

292.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : Let them strike five hundred blows with the horso-goad, five hundred with the Çraŏshô-charana.

293.text: So also for the Jajus, Vijus, Çukurnna, so many for the Urupis with sharp teeth, so many for the Raŏpis the strong9, so many for all the beasts of Cpĕnta-maiuyus of the race of dogs, with the exception of the water-dog.5

294.text: Creator ! Where is the proper place for a dog which belongs to cattle ?

295.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : A Yujyesti from the fold, where he may attack the thief or the wolf.

296.text: Creator ! Where is the proper place for a dog which belongs to a tribe?

297.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : A Hâthra away from the tribe, where he can attack the thief or wolf.

298.text: Creator ! Where isthe proper place for a bloodhound?

299.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : (With him) who wishes not (a dog) for service (?) [but] who wishes a protector for his body.

300.text: Creator! He who gives bad food to a dog belonging to cattle, with what sin does he stain himself?6

301.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : As if in the corporeal world he had given bad food to the master of a noble house, thug does ho stain himself.

302.text: Creator! He who gives bad food to a dog belonging to a village, with what sin does he stain himself?

303.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : As if in the corporeal world he had given bad food to the master of a middling house, thus does he stain himself.

304.text: Creator! He who gives bad food to a bloodhound, with what sin does he stain himself?

305.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : As if he had given bad food to a pure man who comes into the house with such tokens as if he were an Athrava, so does he stain himself,

306.text: Creator ! He who gives bad food to a young dog, with what sin does he stain himself ?

307.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : As if in the corporeal world he were to make a pure youth a sinner [and] give him bad food, so does ho stain himself.

308.text: Creator! He who gives bad food to a dog belonging to cattle,

309.text: What is the punishment for it ?

310.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : Strike his sinful body two hundred strokes with the horse-goad, two hundred with the Çraŏshô-charana.

311.text: What is the punishment for it?

312.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda: Strike ninety blows with the horse-goad, ninety with the Çraŏshô-eharana.

313.text: Creator! He who gives a bloodhound bad food,

314.text: What is the punishment for it ?

315.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda ; Strike seventy blows with the horse-goad, seventy with the Çraŏshô-eharana.

316.text: Creator ; He who gives a young dog bad food,

317.text: What is the punishment for it ?

318.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : Strike fifty blows with the horse-goad, fifty with the Çraŏshô-eharana.

319.text: For in the corporeal world old age most swiftly approaches these of the creatures of Çpĕnta-mainyus, the dogs, 0 holy Zara-thustra,

320.text: Who find themselves along with those who eat, without receiving [anything] to eat.

321.text: Before the dogs who watch that nothing comes;

322.text: Before them shall they place milk and fat along with meat,

323.text: As the proper nourishment for a dog.

324.text: Creator: If in this Mazdayaçnian abode a dog gives no bark * and is not right in his understanding,

326.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : They shall bring a piece of hewn wood to his head.†

327.text: They shall fasten his mouth ‡ therewith ; of the size of a bone of hard (wood), twice as large of soft.

328.text: They shall bind him fast thereto.

329.text: They shall chain him up. [ They shall chain him-self.]

330.text: If not, and this dog who gives no bark and is not in his right senses, wounds a beast or a man,

331.text: Then they shall atone for the wound of the wounded with the punishment of the Baŏdho-varsta.

332.text: If he bites the first beast, (or) wounds the first man, then they shall cut off his right ear.

333.text: If he bites the second beast, wounds the second man, then they shall cut off his left car.

334.text: If he bites a third beast, wounds a third man, they shall cut him in the right foot.7

335.text: if he bites a fourth beast, wounds the fourth man, they shall cut his left foot.

336.text: They shall bind him fast (to [a piece of] wood).

338.text: If not, if the dog who gives no bark and is not in his right senses, wounds a beast or a man ;

339.text: They shall atone for the wound of the wounded with the punishment of the Baŏdhô-vareta.8

340.text: Creator ! If a dog in a Mazdayaçnian dwelling is not in his right senses and right understanding,

341.text: How shall the Mazdayaçnians behave themselves ?

342.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : They shall seek remedies for him just as for any pare man.

343.text: Creator I If he will not take it willingly,

345.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : They shall put a piece of hewn wood on his head,* they shall muzzle his mouth with it ; the size of a bone of hard wood, double the size of soft ; they shall bind him fast thereto, they shall chain him up ; otherwise if this dog -who is not in his right senses falls into a cistern, a well, a pitfall, a stream, or running water,

348.text: Then are they (the Mazdayaçnians) sinners and Pesho-tanus thereby.

349.text: The dog have I made, O Zarathustra, with his own clothing and his own shoes ; ‡

350.text: With keen scent and sharp teeth.

351.text: Faithful to men, as a protection to the folds.

352.text: For I have made the dog, I who am Ahura-Mazda.

353.text: With biting body for the enemy.

354.text: When he is sound, when he is by the fold :

355.text: When, O holy Zarathustra, be is in good voice;

356.text: A thief or a wolf does not come to his tribe and carry away (property) from the village unobserved.9

357.text: The deadly wolf, the wolf who assaults, the growing, flattering wolf.10

358.text: Creator ! Which of these two kinds of wolves is the most pernicious, those which a dog breeds § with a wolf, or those which a wolf breeds with a bitch ?

359.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda: Of these two kinds of wolves, those are the more pernicious, O pure Zarathustra, which a dog breeds with a wolf, [and] next those which a wolf breeds with a bitch. ||

360.text: The dogs which belong to cattle or a village, the bloodhounds and the trained (dogs make their appearance.

361.text: When (the wolves come) to destroy the folds.

362.text: Those who arc [descended from a dog),

363.text: Are more deadly, worse, more pernicious to the folds than other dogs.

364.text: Wolves come forth to destroy the folds.

365.text: Those who are (descended from a wolf),

366.text: Are more deadly, worse, and more destructive to the folds than other wolves.

368.text: One like an Âthrava, one like a warrior, one like a husbandman, one like a villager,* one like a thief, one like a wild beast, † one like a courtesan, one like a child.

369.text: He eats what is offered him like an Âthrava.

370.text: He is contented like an Âthrava.

371.text: He is patient like an Âthrava.

372.text: He needs only a little bread like an Âthrava.

373.text: These are his qualities like those of an Âthrava.

374.text: He goes forward like a warrior.

375.text: He kills ‡ the well-created cow like a warrior.

376.text: He is before and behind the dwelling like a warrior.

377.text: These are hi3 qualities like those of a warrior.

378.text: From his watchfulness he does not take sleep enough, like a husbandman.

379.text: He is before and behind the dwelling § like a husbandman.

380.text: He is behind and before the dwelling like a husbandman.

381.text: These are his qualities like those of a husbandman.11

382.text: He is friendly like a villager. ||

383.text: Wounding when near like a villager.

384.text: House and food are the chiefest to him as to a villager.

385.text: These are his qualities like those of a villager.

386.text: He loves darkness like a thief.

387.text: He runs about in the night¶ “ like a thief.

388.text: He eats undressed ** (food) like a thief.

389.text: He is given to rapine like a thief.

390.text: These are his qualities like those of a thief.

391.text: He loves darkness like a beast of prey.††

392.text: He runs about in the night like a beast of prey.

393.text: He eats raw ‡‡ (meat) like a beast of prey.

394.text: He is given to rapine like a beast of prey.

395.text: These are his qualities like those of a beast of prey.

396.text: He is friendly like a courtesan.

397.text: Wounding from close by like a courtesan.

398.text: To be found on the way like a courtesan.

399.text: House and treasure arc chiefest to him as to a courtesan.

400.text: These are his qualities like those of a courtesan.

401.text: He loves sleep like a child.

402.text: He is fawning like a child.

403.text: He has a long tongue (i.e. he cries often) like a child.

404.text: He runs forwards like a child.

405.text: These are his qualities like those of a child.

406.text: If two (dogs) come to this my dwelling, they shall not drive them away.

407.text: Namely, the dog which belongs to the cattle and to the village.

408.text: For the dwellings would not stand fast on the earth, created by Aliura-Mazda, if there were not dogs which pertain to the cattle and the village.

409.text: Creator ! When a dog dies who begets no more young ones, and has no more seed, where does his spirit go ?

410.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : To the dwelling in the water goes ho, 0 holy Zarathustra ; there come together to him two water-dogs,

411.text: (Which) consist of a thousand male and a thousand female dogs, a pair, one male and one female.

412.text: He who kills a water-dog, he occasions heat which is injurious to the fodder.

413.text: Before,* 0 holy Zarathustra, these regions and places produced food and fatness, healthfulness and remedies, good health, spreading abroad and increase, besides the increase of corn and fodder.12

414.text: Creator! How will Food and fatness, healthfulness and remedies, good health, spreading abroad and increase, prosperity in corn and fodder, come back again to these regions and places ?

415.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda: 0 holy Zarathustra, food and fatness, healthfulness and remedies, good health, spreading abroad and increase, flourishing of corn and fodder, will not come back again to these regions and places.

416.text: Before that (man) who has slain the water-dog is slain in return, or until he brings offerings for the pious soul of the same three days and three nights long,

417.text: At the burning fire, with the Bĕrĕçma bound together, with uplifted Haĕma (then there come back again to these regions and places food and fatness, healthfulness and remedies, good health, spreading abroad and increase, prosperity of com and herbage).

418.text: He who strikes the udra, who lives in the water, who consists of a thousand female and a thousand male dogs, [and] inflicts on him a deadly wound which injures his vital powers :l

419.text: What is the punishment for this ?

420.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda: Let them strike ten thousand blows with the horse-goad, ten thousand with the Çraŏshô-charana.

421.text: Let them give ten thousand loads of hard wood, well-hewn and well-dried, for the fire of Ahura-Mazda, as an atonement for his soul.

422.text: Let them give ten thousand loads of soft wood, Urvâçni, Vôhn-gaôna, Yôhu-kĕrĕti, Hadhâ-naêpata, or any other of the odoriferous woods for the fire of Ahura-Mazda, as an atonement for his soul.

423.text: Let them bind together ten thousand bundles for the Bĕrĕçma.

424.text: Ten thousand Znŏthras with Haŏma and meat, pure and proved, purified with Dahmas, proved with Dahmas, purified with the wood which I call Hadhâ-naêpata, let him give in purity and goodness as an atonement for his soul for the good waters.

425.text: Let him kill ten thousand snakes which creep upon the belly.2

426.text: Let him kill ten thousand serpents which have the bodies of dogs.

427.text: Let him kill ten thousand scorpions.*3

428.text: Let him kill ten thousand lizards† which breathe (i.e. which can live on the land).4

429.text: Let him kill ten thousand lizards which can only live in the water.

430.text: Let him kill ten thousand ants which carry away the corn

431.text: Let him kill ten thousand ants of the evil ones which sting and dig holes. ‡

432.text: Let him kill ten thousand evil gnats.

433.text: Let Lim fill up ten thousand holes in this earth which are full of uncleanness.

434.text: Let him give twice seven (instruments) which have relation to the fire, to the pure man, as an atonement for his soul, in purity and goodness.

435.text: Which go to the fire and kindle the same.

436.text: Which purify (the fire) and spread abroad warmth.

437.text: Which extinguish the fire or fan it.

438.text: Asunder at the netherend, but united at the other (i.e. tonga).

439.text: Let him give to the pure man in purity and goodness, as an atonement for his soul, an axe which cuts swiftly and chops up swiftly, [and] a hammer.*

440.text: Wherewith these Mazdayaçnians may provide themselves with wood for the fire of Ahura-Mazda.

441.text: Let him give to the pure men, in purity and goodness, as an atonement for his soul, all the utensils for a priest;

442.text: Which are the utensils of a priest.

443.text: The fork.† the plate, the Paiti-dâna ;

444.text: (The weapons) wherewith they slay the Khrafetras (which happens) through the Çraŏshô-charana ;

446.text: The mortar which is made according to rule, the cup for the Haŏrna, the Bĕrĕcma.

447.text: All the implements which belong to a warrior let him give to the pure men, in purity and goodness, as an atonement for his soul :

448.text: Which are the implements of a warrior.

449.text: First a lance, second a knife, ‡ third a club ;

451.text: Fifth a bow with a prong (?) and thirty iron points (arrows).

452.text: Sixth a hand-sling and thirty slinging-stones;

453.text: Seventh a coat of mail, eighth a neck-piece ;

454.text: Ninth the Paita-dâna, tenth the helmet;

455.text: Eleventh the girdle, twelfth the greaves §6

456.text: Which are the implements of a husbandman.

457.text: An implement for sowing the corn ;

458.text: A team which is yoked together;

459.text: Whips to drive the cattle with ;

461.text: A handmill whose upper stone grinds ; ||

462.text: Reins which hold in and are strong ;¶

464.text: Creator! How dear when it is of silver ?

465.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda: As much as the price of a male horse.

466.text: Creator ! How dear when it is of gold?

467.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda: As the price of a male camel.

468.text: Let him give to the pure men, in purity and goodness, as an atonement for his soul, a stream with running water.

469.text: Creator ! How large when it is a stream ?

470.text: Then answered Ahara-Mazda : Of the size of a foot, of the hreadth of a foot.

471.text: A field which one can cultivate let him give to the pure men, in purity and goodness, as an atonement for his soul.

472.text: Creator! How, when it is a field?

473.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : Where water comes to light when they dig it up twice.

474.text: A dwelling (with) a cow-stable which contains nine sorts of grass* let him give to the pure men, in purity and goodness, as an atonement for his soul.

475.text: Creator ! How, when it is a dwelling ?

476.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : Twelve Vîtara above, nine in the middle, six below.8

477.text: He should cover the house with a fine matting and give it to the pure men, in purity and goodness, as an atonement for his soul.

478.text: A virgin, who is sound, and has yet known no man, let him give to the pure men, in purity and goodness, as an atonement for his soul.

479.text: Creator! Of what condition must this virgin he?

480.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : Let them betroth a sister, or a daughter, who has a good name and is provided with ear-jewels, to a pure man after her fifteenth year.9

481.text: Let him give fourteen head of small animals to the pure man, in purity and goodness, as an atonement for his soul.

482.text: Let him breed up fourteen dogs.

483.text: Let him make fourteen bridges and running water.

484.text: Let him make eighteen bones † which are not proper and yield no good nourishment into relishing food. ‡

485.text: Let him clean eighteen female ‡ dogs from vermin, the unclean hideous, from all the evils which happen to the dogs.10

486.text: Let him satisfy eighteen pure men with flesh || or (other) food, with Hurâ or wine.11

487.text: That is his punishment, this is his atonement ;

488.text: Which the pure (man) must atone ; if he does not atone,

489.text: Then will he come to the abode of the Drujas (Duzakh).

490.text: By which, when they are committed and not confessed or atoned for,

491.text: One becomes afterwards a sinner and Pêshô-tanus ?

492.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : Five, 0 pure Zarathustra.

493.text: The first of those sins which men commit is :

494.text: When any one calumniates a pure man tu a man of another belief and opinions.*

495.text: He sins knowingly by his own understanding;

496.text: He becomes thereby a sinner and is Peshô-tanus.

497.text: The second of these sins which men commit is :

498.text: If any one gives uneatable bones, or hot food, to a dog which belongs to the cattle or the Tillage ;

499.text: If these bones stick in his teeth or throat ;1

500.text: If these hot victuals burn his mouth or his tongue;

501.text: If he (the dog) injures himself thereby;

503.text: Then he (the man) becomes there by a sinner and Peshô-tanus.

504.text: The third of these sins which men commit is:

505.text: Whoso strikes a pregnant bitch, frightens her, drives her into fear, or claps his hands behind [her] ;2

506.text: If then this bitch falls into a hole, well, trap, river, or running water;

509.text: Thus he (the man) becomes thereby a sinner and Peshŏ-tanus.

510.text: The fourth of the sins which men commit is :

511.text: If any one lies with a woman who is affected with marks, spots, and blood ;

512.text: Thereby he becomes a sinner and Peshô-tanus.

513.text: The fifth of these sins which men commit is :

514.text: If any one lre3 with a pregnant woman, §or a woman who has milk, or a woman who has as yet no milk, but who has conceived ; ¶

517.text: So he becomes thereby a sinner and Peshô-tanus.

518.text: He who goes with a maiden,

519.text: Who is still with her parents or no longer with her parents;3

520.text: Who is betrothed or not betrothed, and makes the same pregnant ;

521.text: Then this maiden must not for shame* of men overstep the mark over trees and water. †

522.text: If this maiden for shame of men oversteps the mark over trees and water ;

524.text: He who goes with a maiden (who is still with her parents or who is no longer with her parents, who is betrothed or not betrothed, and makes the same pregnant) ;4

525.text: Then this maiden must not from shame of men inflict an injury herself upon the fruit of her body.

526.text: If this maiden from shame of men inflicts an injury on the fruit of her body.

527.text: Then she commits a sin for the parents, she wounds for the parents, ‡ for the parents shall they atone for the wound of the wounded with the punishment of the Baôdhô-varsta.

528.text: He who goes with a maiden,

529.text: If then this man says : “ Seek to make thyself friends with an old woman and ask her.”

530.text: If then this maiden makes friends with an old woman and asks her ;

531.text: And this old woman brings Bana or Shaêta,

532.text: Or Ghnâna or Fraçpâta, or any one of the trees which make loose (the embryo) ;

534.text: Then the maiden, the man, and the old woman are alike guilty.5

535.text: He who goes with a maiden ;

536.text: (Who is still with her parents or no longer with her parents, or who is betrothed or not betrothed, and makes her pregnant), he must protect her so long until the child is born.

537.text: If then the child suffers harm because it has no proper nourishment ;

538.text: Then must he atone for the wound of the injured with the punishment of the Baŏdhô-varsta.

540.text: From which of the Mazdayaçnians shall she receive her maintenance?

541.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda: He who goes with a maiden, 57. (Who is with her parents, or no longer with her parents,

542.text: who is betrothed or not betrothed, and makes the same pregnant), he must be her protector until the child is born.

543.text: If he does not provide maintenance,

544.text: Then there is set down to him every birth of the two-footed and the four-footed.

545.text: Of the two-footed, namely, of the maiden ; of the four-footed, namely, of the bitches.6

546.text: Creator! If this bitch lies in,

547.text: From which of the Mazdayaçnians shall she receive her food?

548.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : Whoso has erected the nearest dwelling ; there she receives her food.

549.text: So long must he keep her until the young dogs come out.*

551.text: If these dogs from want of suitable food suffer harm ;

552.text: Then shall he atone for the hurt of the injured with the punishment of the Baôdho--varsta.

553.text: Creator ! If this bitch is brought to bed in the camel-stalls ;7

554.text: From which of the Mazdayaçnians shall she receive her food?

555.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : (From him) who has built this camel-stall.

556.text: He shall maintain her so long ;

557.text: He shall act the protector until that the puppies do come out (can walk along).

559.text: If these dogs suffer harm from want of proper nourishment;

560.text: Then he shall atone for the hurt of the injured with the punishment of the Baŏdhô-varsta.

561.text: Creator! If this bitch is delivered in a horse-stall;

562.text: From which of the Mazdayaçnians shall she receive her food ?

563.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : He who has built this horse-stall :

564.text: He shall keep her so long ;

565.text: He shall protect her so long until the puppies come out.

566.text: If he does not feed them;

567.text: If these dogs suffer harm from “want of proper food ;

568.text: Then he shall atone for the hurt of the injured with the punishment of the Baŏdhô-varsta.

569.text: Creator ! If this hitch lies in, in a cow-stall ;

570.text: From which of the Mazdayacnians shall she receive her food?

571.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : He who has built this cow-stall.

572.text: He shall feed her so long ;

573.text: He shall take care of hex BO long until these puppies come out.

574.text: If he does not feed her;

575.text: If these dogs suffer harm for want of suitable food;

576.text: Then he shall atone for the hurt of the injured with the punishment of the Baŏdhô-varsta,

577.text: Creator! If this bitch lies in, in a cattle-pen ;*

578.text: From which of the Mazdayaenians shall she receive her food?

579.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda ; He who has built this cattle-pen ;

580.text: He shall feed her so long ;

581.text: He shall take care of her so long until the puppies come out.

582.text: If he does not feed them;

583.text: If these puppies suffer harm from want of proper food ;

584.text: Then they shall atone for the harm of the injured with the punishment of the Baŏdhô-varsta.

585.text: Creator ! If this bitch is delivered in the stack ; †

586.text: From which of the Mazdayacnians shall she receive food?

587.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : He who built the stack ;

589.text: He shall take care of her so long until the puppies come out.

590.text: If he gives them no food ;

591.text: If these puppies suffer harm for want of proper food ;

592.text: Then shall they atone for the harm of the injured with the punishment of the Baŏdhô-varsta.

593.text: Creator ! If this bitch comes to light ‡ in a cellar ;

594.text: From which of the Mazdayacnians shall she receive food ‘‘.

595.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda: He who has dug this cellar.

597.text: He shall take care of her so long until the puppies come out. If he gives them no food, and these puppies suffer harm for want of proper food, then they shall atone for the hurt of the injured with the punishment of the Baŏdhô-varsta.

598.text: Creator! If this bitch is delivered in the hay ;

599.text: From which of the Mazdayaçniana shall she receive food ?

600.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda: He who has made this meadow ;

601.text: He shall feed her so long;

602.text: Let them carry them to his house on a mat of plants or any other bed ;

603.text: He shall take care (of them) so long until the puppies come out.

604.text: If he gives them no food ;

605.text: If these dogs suffer harm for want of proper food ;

606.text: Then they shall atone for the harm of the injured with the punishment of the Baŏdhô-varsta.

607.text: Creator ! When have these dogs their own utensils and their own bread ? *

608.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : When these dogs can run round about twice seven dwellings ;

609.text: Then they go forwards at will, in winter as in summer.

610.text: Six months let them protect the dogs, seven years long the children.

738.text: “ Put on thy clothes, wash thine hands, seek fire-wood and bring it hither to me, make me shining with the pure firewood, with washed hands.”

741.text: “ Put on thy clothes, wash thine hands, seek fire-wood, bring it hither to me, make me shining with the pure fire-wood, with washed hands, else the Âzîs created by the Daevas might come, who appears to snatch me from the world.”

Then lifts up this bird his voice at every divine dawn : “ Stand up, ye men, praise the best purity, destroy the Daevas, there runs up to you the Daeva Rushyançta with long hands, this sends to sleep again the whole corporeal world when it is awakened. 1219.text: I praise thee, 0 Çaôka, good, created by Ahura-Mazda, pure.

1221.text: I praise thee, 0 Çaôka, good, created by Ahura-Mazda, pure.

1222.text: I will give thee as a recompense a thousand head of small cattle, fed, of all kinds.

1223.text: I praise thee, 0 Çaôka, good, created by Ahura-Mazda, pure.

Therefore do thou heal me, 0 desirable Airyama.
