1248.text: What is in the first place most acceptable to this earth?

1249.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : “Where a holy man walks about, 0 holy Zarathustra,

1250.text: Offering-wood in the hand, Bereçma in the hand, the cup in the hand, the mortar in the hand,

1251.text: In accordance with the law speaking these words: Mithra with his broad territories will I invoke, and Ràma-qaçtra.*1

1252.text: Creator of the corporeal world, Pure One!

1253.text: What is in the second place most acceptable to this earth?

1254.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : That a holy man should build himself there a habitation,

1255.text: Provided with fire, provided with cattle, provided with a

1256.text: Then is there in this habitation abundance of cattle, abundance of righteousness, abundance of provender, of dogs, of women, of youths,† of fire, of all that is requisite for a good life.2

1257.text: Creator of the corporeal world, Pure One !

1258.text: What is in the third place most acceptable to this earth?

1259.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : Where by cultivation there is produced, 0 holy Zarathustra, most corn, provender, and fruit-bearing trees ;3

1260.text: Where dry land is watered, or the water is drained from the too-moist land.4

1261.text: Creator of the corporeal world, Pure One !

1262.text: What is in the fourth place most acceptable to this earth ?

1263.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : Where most cattle and beasts of burden are born.5

1264.text: Creator of the corporeal world, Pure One!

1265.text: What is in the fifth place most acceptable to this earth ?

1266.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda: Where cattle and beasts of burden most leave their urine.

1267.text: Creator of the corporeal world, Pure One!

1268.text: What is in the first place most displeasing to thi3 earth ?

1269.text: Thereupon answered Ahura-Mazda: The conception of the Arezura,‡ 0 holy Zarathustra;6

1270.text: When the Daevas with the Drujas come together to it out of hell.

1271.text: Creator of the corporeal world, Pure One !

1272.text: What is in the second place most displeasing to this earth ?

1273.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : Where most dead dogs and dead men are buried in it.

1274.text: Creator of the corporeal world, Pure One !

1275.text: What is in the third place most displeasing to this earth ?

1276.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : Where most heaps of Dakhmas are made, where they lay upon them dead men.

1277.text: Creator of the corporeal world, Pure One!

1278.text: What is in the fourth place most displeasing to this earth?

1279.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda ; Where are most holes of the (beasts) created by Ahriman.

1280.text: Creator of the corporeal world, Pure One !

1281.text: What is in the fifth place most displeasing to this earth ?

1282.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : When, 0 holy Zarathustra, the wife or son of a [deceased] righteous man goes in the way of perversity,*

1283.text: And makes lamentations, covered with earth and dust.7

1284.text: Creator of the corporeal world, Pure One !

1285.text: Who first rejoices this earth with the greatest joy ?

1286.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : He who especially digs up where dead men and dogs are buried.

1287.text: Creator of the corporeal world, Pure One !

1288.text: Who secondly rejoices this earth with the greatest joy?

1289.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : He who especially levels the Dakhmas where dead men are laid down.

1290.text: No where shall a single [man] carry a dead body.

1291.text: If a single [man] carries it, the dead body,

1292.text: The Naçus defiles [him] from the nose, from the eyes, from the tongue, from the face,”from the back.†

1293.text: On their nails (i.e. of those who commit this sin) springs ‡ this Drukhs Naçus,

1294.text: And they are unclean hereafter for ever and ever.

1295.text: Creator of the corporeal world, Pure One !

1296.text: Where is the place for the men who carry the dead ?

1297.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : It must be the most waterless and treeless [part] of this earth ;

1299.text: Where the cattle and beasts of burden least walk along the ways :

1300.text: And the fire of Ahura-Mazda, and the Bëreçma that is bound in holiness, and the holy man.

1301.text: Creator of the corporeal world, Pure One !

1302.text: How far from fire, how far from water, how far from the Bërëçma which is bound together, how far from the pure man?

1303.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda: Thirty paces from the fire, thirty paces from the water, thirty paces from the Berëçma which is bound together, three paces from the pure man.

1304.text: So shall these Mazdayaçnians heap up a heap upon this earth there-for.

1305.text: Afterwards with food shall these Mazdayaçnians bring them, here, afterwards with clothes shall these Mazdayaçnians bring them here.

1308.text: This food shall [they] eat, these clothes shall [they] wear ;

1309.text: All, even to the aged, the old who have no more seed.

1310.text: After that whatever is aged, old, and has no more seed.—

1311.text: Strong, swift, and pure, the Mazdayaçnians shall afterwards leave ‡ him upon the mountains.

1312.text: At the broad of his back shall they cut off his head. Let them give the body to the devouring creatures of Çpenta-main-yus, to the carnivorous birds and Kahrkâças.

1313.text: Thus let them say : “ This one repents himself of all evil in thoughts, words, and deeds.”

1314.text: “ If he has committed other sinful deeds ; “

1315.text: “ The punishment is confessed § [i.e. is remitted through confession].

1316.text: “ If he has not committed other sinful deeds ; “

1318.text: Creator of the corporeal world, Pure One !

1319.text: Who thirdly rejoices this earth with the greatest joy?

1320.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : He who most levels (fills up) the holes of the creatures of Anra-mainyus.

1321.text: Creator of the corporeal world, Pure One !

1322.text: Who fourthly rejoices this earth with the greatest joy ?

1323.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : He who most cultivates the fruits of the field, grass and trees, which yield food, O holy Zarathustra.

1324.text: Or, ho who provides waterless land with water, or gives water to the waterless (land).

1325.text: Fur the earth is not glad which lays long uncultivated.

1327.text: Then is it good for a habitation for these (men).9

1328.text: There the cattle increase, which long went childless.

1329.text: Then is it good for the male beasts.

1330.text: He who cultivates this earth with the left arm and the right, with the right arm and the left, 0 holy Zarathustra,

1332.text: Like as a friend to his beloved she brings to him issue or riches, whilst he lays down stretched out.

1333.text: He who cultivates this earth, 0 holy Zarathustra, with the left arm and the right, with the right arm and the left.

1334.text: Then this earth speaks to him : Man ! thou who cultivatest me with the left arm and the right, with the right arm and the left,

1335.text: Always will I come hither and bear.

1336.text: All food will I bear, together with the fruits of the field.

1337.text: He who does not cultivate this earth, 0 holy Zarathustra, with the left arm and the right, with the right arm and left,

1338.text: Then this earth speaks to him : Man ! thou who dost not cultivate me with the left arm and right, with the right arm and left,

1339.text: Always thou standest there, going to the doors of others to beg for food.

1340.text: Always they bring food to you, thou who beggest lazily out of doors. †

1341.text: They bring to you out of their superfluity of good things.

1342.text: Creator of the corporeal world, Pure One !

1343.text: What is the increase of the Mazdayaçnian law?

1344.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda: When one diligently cultivates corn, 0 holy Zarathustra.

1345.text: He who cultivates the fruits of the field cultivates purity.

1347.text: He spreads ‡ the Mazdayaçnian law abroad

1351.text: When there ere crops then the Daevas hiss, §

1352.text: When there are shoots then the Daevas cough, ||

1353.text: When there are stalks then the Daevas weep ¶

1354.text: When there are thick ears of corn then the Daevaa fly.*11

1355.text: There are the Daevas most smitten in the dwelling-places where the ears of corn are found.

1356.text: To hell they go, melting like glowing ice. †12

1357.text: After that let this Manthra be recited :

1358.text: “ No one, if he eats nothing, has any strength ;

1359.text: “He is not able to be of pure conduct,

1360.text: “ Not (able) to be employed in cultivation : ‡

1361.text: “Since with food lives the whole corporeal world, and without food it dies.”

1362.text: Creator of the corporeal world, Pure One !

1363.text: Who fifthly rejoices this earth with the greatest joy 1

1364.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda: When one, 0 holy Zara-thustra, labours on this earth for the holy man—[but] if he does not give in holiness ;13

1365.text: He will be thrown from off this Çpëhta-ârmaiti (earth) into darkness;

1366.text: Into sorrow, into the very worst places ;

1368.text: Creator of the corporeal world, Pure One !

1369.text: If one buries in this earth dead dogs and dead men and does not dig them up again for half a year; §

1370.text: What is the punishment for this ?15

1371.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : Let them strike him five hundred blows with the horse-goad, five hundred with the Çraoshô-charana. ||16

1372.text: Creator of the corporeal world, Pure One !

1373.text: When one buries in this earth dead dogs and dead men and does not dig them up again for a year ;

1374.text: What is the punishment for this !

1375.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : Let them strike him a thousand blows with the horse-goad, a thousand with the Çraoshô-charana.

1376.text: Creator of the corporeal world, Pure One !

1377.text: When one buries in this earth dead dogs and dead men and does not dig them up again for two years ;

1381.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda: For this there is no punpopshment ; for this there is no atonement ; for this there is no purification ;

1382.text: For these inexpiable deeds for evermore.

1383.text: [They are to be atoned for] In the following manner:17

1384.text: (It is asked) Whether any one praises and hears the Mazdayaçnian law.

1385.text: Or whether any one does not praise and hear the Mazdayaçnian law ;

1386.text: Since it (the law) will take away these (sins) from those who praise the Mazdayaçnian law,

1387.text: If afterwards they do not again commit wicked deeds.

1388.text: For this Mazdayaçnian law, 0 holy Zarathustra, takes away the bonds from the man who praises it.

1390.text: It takes away the murder of a pure man.

1391.text: It takes away the burying of the dead.

1392.text: It takes away the inexpiable deeds.

1393.text: It takes away the high sin of debts.19

1394.text: It takes away all the sins that one commits.

1395.text: In this wise, 0 holy Zarathustra, does the Mazdayaçnian law take away all the evil thoughts, words and deeds, of a pure man, even as the strong swift wind clears the sky from the right side.

1396.text: “Well is it here, 0 Zarathustra, when one has performed good works.

1397.text: Where the good become lords over the bad. 4. Where the fruits of the earth are shared with the Yazatas and the good. 5. Where the Zaothra and Yaçua are offered.

1398.text: Is a thief of the loan, a robber of what is lent to him ; *

1399.text: For him (the debtor) one must preserve night and day as well as (his own property).1

1400.text: Creator! How many are these thy Mithras [i.e. contracts] Ahura-Mazda’a ?

1401.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : Six, 0 pure Zarathustra—

1402.text: The first takes place with the word.

1404.text: The third is of the value of a bullock.

1405.text: The fourth of the value of a beast of burden.

1406.text: The fifth of the value of a man.†

1407.text: The sixth of the value of a tract of land—-

1408.text: Namely of a tract which has good increase, is wide, fruitful, strong, and profitable.’2

1409.text: The word makes the first Mithra ‡

1410.text: The value of a hand takes it afterwards away.

1411.text: He gives afterwards, as an atonement, of the value of a hand;

1412.text: That of the value of a bullock takes it then away.

1413.text: Then he gives atonement of the value of a bullock; §

1414.text: That of the value of a beast of burden takes it then away.

1415.text: Then he gives atonement of the value of a beast of burden ;

1416.text: That of the value of a man || takes it away.

1417.text: Then he gives atonement of the value of a man ;

1418.text: That of the value of a tract of land takes it away.

1419.text: Then he gives atonement of the value of a tract of land.3

1420.text: Creator ! With how much does the contract when broken ¶ affect [i.e. pollute or make guilty] which is committed by the word ? 4

1421.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : With three hundred similar punishments * which it brings upon the nearest relations.

1422.text: Creator ! With how much does the contract when broken affect which is committed by the joining hands?

1423.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : With six hundred similar punishments which it brings upon the nearest relations.

1424.text: Creator ! With how much does that breach of contract affect of the value of a bullock ?

1425.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : With seven hundred similar punishments which it brings upon the nearest relations.

1426.text: Creator ! With how much does the breach of contract affect of the value of a beast of burden ?

1427.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : With eight hundred similar punishments which it brings upon the nearest relations.

1428.text: Creator ! With how much does the breach of contract affect of the value of a man †

1429.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda: With nine hundred similar punishments which it brings upon the nearest relations.

1430.text: Creator ! With how much does that breach of contract affect of the value of a tract of land ?

1431.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda: With a thousand similar punishments which it brings upon the nearest relations.

1432.text: Creator! He who breaks a Mithra (contract) in words; ‡

1433.text: What is the punishment for it?

1434.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda ; Let them strike three hundred blows with the horse-goad, three hundred with the Çraosho-charana.

1435.text: Creator ! He who breaks the Mithra of the value of a hand ;

1436.text: What is the punishment for it?

1437.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda: Let them strike six hundred strokes with the horse-goad, six. hundred with the Çraoshô-charana.

1438.text: Creator! He who breaks a Mithra of the value of a bullock ;

1439.text: What is the punishment for it ?

1440.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : Let them strike seven hundred strokes with the horse-goad, seven hundred with the Çraoshô-charana.

1441.text: Creator ! He who breaks a Mithra of the value of a beast of burden :

1442.text: What is the punishment for it?

1443.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : Let them strike eight hundred strokes with the horse-goad, eight hundred with the Çraoshô-charana.

1444.text: Creator ! He who breaks a Mithra of tie value of a man ; *

1445.text: What is the punishment for it?

1446.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : Let them strike nine hundred strokes with the horse-goad, nine hundred with the Çraoshô-charana.

1447.text: Creator ! He who breaks a Mithra of the value of a tract of land ;

1448.text: What is the punishment for it ?

1449.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda: Let them strike a thousand strokes with the horse-goad, a thousand with the Çraoshô-charana.

1450.text: He who prepares to strike a man that is to him Âgerepta ;

1451.text: If he knocks him down it is to him Avaöirista ;

1452.text: If revenge sits in his mind it is to him Aredus.5

1453.text: At the fifth of the sins Aredus (the man) fills up his body [i.e. with sin].6

1454.text: Creator ! He who commits the Âgerepta on a, man ;

1455.text: What is the punishment for it?

1456.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : Strike five strokes with the horse-goad, and five with the Çraoshô-charana ;

1457.text: The second time strike ten strokes with the horse-goad, ten with the Çraoshô-charana ;

1458.text: The third time strike fifteen strokes with the horse-goad, fifteen with the Çraoshô-charana ;

1459.text: The fourth time strike thirty strokes with the horse-goad, thirty with the Çraoshô-charana ;

1460.text: The fifth time strike fifty strokes with the horse-goad, fifty with the Çraoshô-charana;

1461.text: The sixth time strike sixty † strokes with the horse-goad, sixty with the Çraoshô-charana;

1462.text: The seventh time strike seventy ‡ strokes with the borse-goad, seventy with the Çraoshô-charana.

1463.text: If he commits this deed for the eighth time without the former being atoned for ;

1464.text: What is the punishment for it ?

1465.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : Let them strike this sinful body two hundred blows with the horse-goad, two hundred with the Çraoshô-charana.7

1466.text: Creator ! If he who has committed Âgerepta on a man has not atoned for it ;

1468.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : Let them strike his sinful body two hundred blows with the horse-goad, two hundred with the Çraoshô-charana.

1470.text: What is the punishment for it ?

1471.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : Let them strike ten strokes with the horse-goad, ten with the Çraoshô-charana; the second time fifteen strokes with the horse-goad, fifteen with the Çraoshô-charana ; the third time strike thirty blows with the horse-goad, thirty with the Çraoshô-charana ; the fourth time fifty blows with the horse-goad, fifty with the Çraoshô-charana; the fifth time strike seventy blows with the horse-goad, seventy with the Çraoshô-charana; the sixth time strike ninety blows with the horse-goad, ninety with the Çraoshô-charana. If he commits the deed the seventh time without having made atonement for the former times, what is the punishment for it? Then answered Ahura-Mazda: Let them strike his sinful body two hundred blows with the horse-goad, two hundred with the Çraoshô-charana.

1472.text: Creator! If he who has committed the Avaöirista does not atone for it.

1473.text: What is the punishment for it ?

1474.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : Let thorn strike his sinful body two hundred blows with the horse-goad, two hundred with the Çraoshô-charana.

1475.text: Creator ! He who smites a man with the blow Aredus; *

1476.text: What is the punishment for it ?

1477.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : Let them strike fifteen blows with the horse-goad, fifleen with the Çraoshô-charana ; the second time thirty strokes with the horse-goad, thirty with the Çraoshô-charana ; the third time strike fifty blows with the horse-goad, fifty with the Çraoshô-charana ; the fourth time strike seventy blows with the horse-goad, seventy with the Çraoshô-charana : the fifth time strike ninety blows with the horse-goad, ninety with the Çraoshô-charana. If he commits this deed the sixth time without having made atonement for the former times, what is the punishment for it? Then answered Ahura-Mazda: Let them strike his sinful body two hundred blows with the horse-goad, two hundred with the Çraoshô-charana.

1478.text: Creator ! If he who has injured a man with the stroke Aredus does not make atonement for it ;

1479.text: What is the punishment for it?

1480.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda: Let them strike his sinful body two hundred blows with the horse-goad, two hundred with the Çraoshô-charana.

1481.text: Creator ! If a man strikes a hard sore * on a man,8

1482.text: What is the punishment for it ?

1483.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : Strike thirty strokes with the horäe-goad, thirty with the Çraoshô-charana.

1484.text: The second time strike fifty blows with the horse-goad, and fifty with the Çraoshô-charana.

1485.text: The third time strike seventy blows with the horse-goad, seventy with the Çraoshô-charana; the fourth time strike ninety blows with the horse-goad, ninety with the Çraoshô-charana. If he commits the deed the fifth time without having atoned for the former, what is the punishment? Then answered Ahura-Mazda: Let them strike his sinful body two hundred blows with the horse-goad, two hundred with the Çraoshô-charana.

1486.text: Creator ! If he who has struck a hard sore on a man does not atone for it ;

1487.text: What is the punishment for it ?

1488.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : Let them strike his sinful body two hundred blows with the horse-goad, two hundred with the Çraǒshô-charana.

1489.text: Creator ! He who wounds a man so that the blood flows ;

1490.text: What is the punishment for it?

1491.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : Let them strike fifty strokes with the horse-goad, fifty -with the Çraǒshô-charana; the second time strike seventy blows with the horse-goad, seventy ?with the Çraǒshô-charana ; the third time ninety blows with the horse-goad, ninety with the Çraǒshô-charana. If he commits the deed a fourth time without having atoned for the former, what is the punishment for it ? Then answered Ahura-Mazda : Let them strike his sinful body two hundred strokes with the horse-goad, two hundred with the Çraǒshô-charana.

1492.text: Creator ! If he who has wounded a man so that the blood comes, does not atone for it ;

1494.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : Let them strike his sinful body two hundred strokes with the horse-goad, two hundred with the Çraǒshô-charana.

1495.text: Creator ! He who strikes any one a blow so as to break a bone ;

1496.text: What is the punishment for it ?

1497.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda: Let them strike seventy strokes with the horse-goad, seventy with the Çraǒ’shô-charana ; the second time strike ninety blows with the horse-goad, ninety with the Çraǒshô-charana.

1498.text: If he commits the deed the third time without having atoned for the former, what is the punishment for it ?

1499.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : Let them strike his sinful body two hundred strokes with the horse-goad, two hundred with the Çraǒshô-charana.

1500.text: Creator! If he who has wounded a man so that a bone has been broken, does not atone for it ;

1501.text: What is the punishment there-for? Then answered Ahura-Mazda : Let them strike his sinful body two hundred blows with the horse-goad, two hundred with the Çraǒsho-charana.

1502.text: Creator! He who inflicts a dangerous wound on a man ;

1503.text: What is the punishment for it?

1504.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : Let them strike ninety blows with the horse-goad, ninety with the Çraoshô-charana.

1505.text: If be commits this deed the second time without having atoned for the first ;

1507.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : Let them strike his sinful body two hundred strokes with the horse-goad, two hundred with the Çraǒshô-charana.

1508.text: Creator! If he who has inflicted a dangerous wound on a man, does not atone for it ;

1510.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : Let them strike his sinful body two hundred blows with the horse-goad, two hundred with the Çraǒshô-charana.

1513.text: According to the precept of purity.

1514.text: If then, men, in conformity with the law * come hither, a brother or a friend,

1515.text: Desirous (to atone) with gold or with women, or with the understanding—

1516.text: If they wish (to atone) with gold they may bring gold hither.

1517.text: If they wish (to atone) by means of women they may bring hither women.

1518.text: If they wish (to atone) by the understanding they may recite the Manthra-çpenta.

1519.text: Within the first and second (part) of the day, within the first and second (part) of the night.

1520.text: For the increase of the understanding which withdraws itself from purity.†

1521.text: Through purity and prayer for the increase of the understanding, in order that it may ever remain.

1522.text: To the middle of the day, and in the night, without sleeping either by day or in the night,

1523.text: Until they have spoken all these words which the Her-beds have spoken :

1524.text: Which they have made for men with seething waters, * 0 Zarathustra.

1525.text: One must not speak contrary to the law concerning flesh or concerning pasture.†

1526.text: With regard to the married, ‡ I call them, 0 holy Zarathustra, before him

1528.text: Him who has a household before him who has none ; the father of a family before the childless ;

1530.text: For he seeks most among other men to protect the Vôhu-manô who furthers the increase of cattle, before him who does it not.

1531.text: If he then is dead (viz. who furthers the increase of cattle),

1532.text: He is of the value of an Aspĕrĕna, of the value of a lesser animal, of the value of a beast of burden, of the value of a man.

1533.text: For this man—if one repents—wars with the Asta-vidhôtus ;

1534.text: He wars with the Ishus Qâthakhtô ;

1535.text: He wars with Zemaka (the Demon of winter) and puts on him a smaller garment; ||

1536.text: He wars against the brain of wicked men ;

1537.text: He wars against Ashemaögho, the impure, who eats nothing. ¶10

1538.text: If he has committed this deed for the first time, not for second time ;

1539.text: If they become aware of these deeds in the corporeal world;

1540.text: Let them begin to cut the bones, with iron knives,

1541.text: Of his body worthy of decay ; or even more.

1542.text: Let them fasten iron fetters on the bones

1543.text: Of the body worthy of decay ; or even more.

1544.text: If they become aware of this deed in the corporeal world,

1545.text: He causes a hundred men to fall without wishing it.

1546.text: On account of his body worthy of decay ; and even more than that.

1547.text: If they become aware of this deed in the corporeal world,

1548.text: Thus he commits without knowing it a great sin ;

1549.text: If they become aware of this deed in the corporeal world,

1550.text: (Then it is as if) he were knowingly to approach the hot golden boiling water lyingly, * as if speaking truth, (but) lying to Mithra.11

1551.text: Creator ! He who knowingly approaches the hot golden boiling water, as if speaking truth, but lying to Mithra ;

1552.text: What is the punishment for it?

1553.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda: Let them strike seven hundred blows with the horse-goad, seven hundred with the Çraŏshô-charana.

1554.text: Which man to perform neyaesh not worship sublime may take away. Gloss : So is the man who ought to perform neyaesh and. dots not do it.

1555.text: Thief of Neyaosh he is become guilty thief debt taking away. Gloss : That man is a stealer of Neyaesh and is held guilty. Again it is declared in the Avesta, that if a man incurs a debt with a view not to pay it back, and afterwards tags, The man that gave mô [the money’] does not remember it; he is a first-rate, thief; he is as guilty as if he. actually stole the property of another. From such a transgression Daruj obtains pregnancy.

1556.text: He as if in the midst of the day in the midst of the night habitation himself high may keep. Gloss : That man is like one that, having abused kindness [cf. Sadder xxviii.] is held guilty day and night.

1557.text: Hither fly the birds from the heights of the mountains down to the depths of the vallies,

1558.text: Down to this body of the dead man, and devour it.

1559.text: Then the birds 3y up again from the depths of the vallies to the heights of the mountains ;

1560.text: They fly to a tree, either a hard or a soft one ; *

1561.text: † They vomit on it, they dung it, they deposit on it (part of the corpse).

1562.text: A man goes up from the depths of the valley to the heights of the mountain ;

1563.text: He goes to the tree where the bird is—he wishes firewood for the fire—?

1564.text: He fells thi3 tree, he cuts it in pieces, he cleaves it, he burns it with the fire, the Son of Ahura-Mazda;

1565.text: What is the punishment for this ?

1566.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : No corpse which has been carried away by dogs, birds, wolves, winds, or flies, defiles a man.1

1567.text: Were these corpses which have been carried away by dogs, birds, wolves, winds, or flies, to defile men,

1568.text: Then would almost all my corporeal world be little allied to purity, but become Khraöjdat-urva and Peshô-tanus;2

1569.text: On account of the multitude of these corpses which have perished on this earth.

1570.text: Creator! A man pours water over a corn-field ;

1571.text: The water flows over this field for the second, for the third time;

1572.text: After the fourth time a dog, or a panther, or a wolf, brings a corpse into the field ;

1573.text: What is the punishment for this ?

1574.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda: No corpse which the dogs, birds, wolves, winds, or flies, have brought defiles a man,

1575.text: Were these corpses which dogs, birds, wolves, wind3, or flies, have brought to defile men,

1576.text: Then in a short time my whole corporeal world would little love purity, but become Khraǒjdat’urva and Peshô-tanus ;

1577.text: On account of the number of these corpses which have perished on the earth.

1578.text: Creator ! Does the water destroy a man ?

1579.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : The water does not destroy a man.

1580.text: Açtô—Vîdhôtus binds him, * the birds carry the bound one away;3

1581.text: The water carries him up, the water carries him down, the water washes him ;

1582.text: Afterwards the birds eat him up.

1583.text: There (in the other world) he goes up and down by destiny.4

1584.text: Creator! Does the fire destroy a man?

1585.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : Fire destroys no man.

1586.text: Açtô-Vîdhôtus binds him,† the birds ‡ carry away the bound one,

1587.text: The fire burns his bones and his vital principle.

1588.text: There (in the other world) he goes up and down by destiny.

1589.text: Creator 1 When the summer is over, then in winter5

1591.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda: In every house, in every village, they shall erect three Katas §; for him who is dead.

1592.text: Creator ! How shall these Katas for the dead be made ?

1593.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : They shall not touch against the uplifted head ;

1594.text: They shall not reach farther than his feet and his hands;

1595.text: For this is the lawful Rata for a dead body.

1596.text: There shall they lay down the soulless bodies during two nights, three nights, or a month long.

1597.text: Until the birds fly up, the trees grow up,

1598.text: The pernicious ones (the Daevas)|| hasten away, and the wind makea the earth dry.6

1599.text: After this, when the birds fly away, the trees grow up, the pernicious ones ¶ hasten away, and the wind makes the earth dry;

1600.text: Then shall the Mazdayaçnians expose these bodies to the Sun.

1601.text: If the Mazdayaçnians do not expose the bodies to the Sun,

1602.text: Command thou the same punishment for a year long that is prescribed for the murder of a pure man.

1603.text: Until the corpses are purified, the Dakhmas purified, the uncleanness is carried away, and the birds have eaten (the corpse).

1604.text: Creator ! Dost thou, who art Ahura-Mazda, bring the water

1605.text: Out of the sea Vôuru-kasha with Wind and Clouds ?7

1606.text: Dost thou bring it down to the corpses, Thou who art Ahura-Mazda ? Dost thou bring it to the Dakhma, Thou who art Ahura-Mazda? Dost thou bring it to uncleanness, Thou who art Ahura-Mazda? Dost thou pour it over the bones, Thou who art Ahura-Mazda? Dost thou bring it away clandestinely (nobody perceiving it), Thou who art Ahura-Mazda?

1607.text: Dost thou bring these things to the sea Pûitika ?

1608.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda: It is as thou, 0 Zara-thustra ! who art pure, sayest.

1609.text: The water bring I away, I who am Ahura-Mazda, from the sea Vôuru-kasha with wind and clouds ;

1610.text: I bring it to the corpses, I who am Ahura-Mazda ; I bring it to the Dakhma, I who am Ahura-Mazda ; I bring it to uncleanness, I who am Ahura-Mazda ; I pour it over the bones, I who am Ahura-Mazda; I bring it away secretly, I who am Ahura-Mazda.

1611.text: I bring these things to the sea Pûitika : they are seething in the midst of the sea.

1612.text: Purified do the waters flow from out the sea Pûitika to the sea Vôuru-kasha.

1614.text: There grow my trees, all, of all kinds.

1615.text: These I cause to be rained down from thence, I who am Ahura-Mazda ;

1616.text: As food for the pure man, as fodder for the cow created by the good [principle, Ahura-Mazda].*

1617.text: The corn may men eat, the pastures are for the cow created by the good [principle].

1618.text: This is the Good, this is the Beautiful, as Thou who art pure sayest.

1619.text: By these words the pure Ahura-Mazda rejoiced him, the pure Zarathustra.

1620.text: Purity is the best thing formen after birth.8

1621.text: This is purity, 0 Zarathustra ! the Mazdayacnian law.

1622.text: He who keeps himself pure by good thoughts, words, and deeds.

1623.text: Creator! How is the greatness, goodness, and beauty in this Zarathustrian law, given against the Daevas (Vendidad), which is great, good, and beautiful above all other words ?

1624.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda: Similarly, 0 holy Zara-

1625.text: As the sea Vôuru-kasha is higher than other waters,

1626.text: As the greater waters flow superior to the lesser,

1627.text: As the greater trees surpass the smaller,

1628.text: As (the heavens) are around this earth.

1629.text: Spoken by Ratu,* spoken by Çraoshâvarëza,9

1630.text: With an uplifted Draöna,† or one not uplifted,

1633.text: The Ratu can remit him a third part of the punishment.

1634.text: If he has committed other sinful deeds,

1635.text: Then the punishment is repented [i.e. remitted through repentance];

1636.text: If he has not committed other sinful deeds (i.e. spiritual), then they are repented of for ever.10

1637.text: Creator ! If men are in the same house together, on the same bed, or on the same mat,

1639.text: Or five, or fifty, or a hundred, together with their wives : §

1640.text: Then one of these men dies,—on how many of the men does the Drukhs Naçus settle with corruption, rottenness, and filth?11

1641.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : If it is a priest, 0 holy Zarathustra, the Drukhs Naçus rushes up;12

1642.text: If it comes to the eleventh it defiles the tenth.

1643.text: If it is a warrior, 0 holy Zarathustra, the Drukhs Naçus rushes up ;

1644.text: If it comes to the tenth it defiles the ninth.

1645.text: If it is a husbandman, 0 holy Zarathustra, the ;Drukha Naçus runs up;

1646.text: If it comes to the ninth it defiles the eighth.

1647.text: If it is a dog belonging to cattle, 0 holy Zarathustra, the Drukhs Naçus runs up ;

1648.text: If it comes to the eighth it defiles the seventh.

1649.text: If it is a dog belonging to a village, 0 holy Zarathustra, the Drukhs Naçus rushes up ;

1650.text: If it comes to the seventh it defiles the sixth.

1651.text: If it is a dog, a bloodhound, ||13 0 holy Zarathustra, the Drnkhs Naçu3 runs up ;

1652.text: If it comes to the sixth it defiles the fifth.

1653.text: If it is a young dog, 0 holy Zarathustra, the Drukhs Naçus rushes up ;

1654.text: If it comes to the fifth it defiles the fourth.

1655.text: If it is a dog which cannot see,* 0 holy Zarathustra, the Drukhs Naçus rushes up ;

1656.text: If it comes to the fourth it defiles the third.

1657.text: If it is a dog just born, 0 holy Zarathustra, the Drukhs Naçus runs up ;

1658.text: If it comes to the third it defiles the second.

1659.text: If it is a dog just come to life, O holy Zarathustra, the Drukhs Naçus runs up ;

1660.text: If it comes to the second it defiles the first.

1661.text: If it is a dog as yet without life,† O holy Zarathustra, the Drukhs Naçus runs up.

1662.text: If it comes to the first it defiles the first.

1663.text: Creator ! If it is the dog Urupis,‡

1664.text: How many creatures of Çpenta-mainyus does the dog Urupis defile directly ? how many indirectly ?

1665.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda: The dog Urupis does not defile the creatures of Çpenta-mainyus, neither directly nor indirectly,

1666.text: Except the person who strikes or kills him :

1668.text: Creator ! If it is a pernicious, bad two-legged being, a very noxious and impure one, ||

1669.text: How many creatures of Çpenta-mainyus does it defile directly ? how many indirectly ?

1670.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : Like a lizard ¶ whose moisture is dried up, which has been dead above a year.14

1671.text: For living, O holy Zarathustra 1 the pernicious being, the two-legged one, very noxious and impure (defiles) :

1672.text: It defiles the creatures of Çpenta-mainyus directly;

1674.text: Living, it injures the water; living, it extinguishes the fire ; living, it leads the cattle the wrong way ; living, it smites the pure man a blow which injures his consciousness and his vital power ; but not so when it is dead.

1675.text: For whilst it is alive, O holy Zarathustra! this deadly serpent, the two-footed, is very hurtful and impure ;

1676.text: (Living), it takes the pure man away from the world, food, pastures, trees, bushes, and iron; but not so when it is dead.

1677.text: Creator ! We bring to the habitations in this corporeal world, O pure Ahura-Mazda ! fire, the Bëreçma, the cup, the Haoma, and the mortar.

1678.text: If afterwards a dog or a man dies in this habitation,

1679.text: How shall the Mazdayaçnians conduct themselves?

1680.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda: They shall bring out from this habitation, 0 holy Zarathustra! the fire, the Bëreçma, the cup, the Haöma, and the mortar.

1681.text: They shall bring out the dead body;

1682.text: Like as a man, according to the law, is brought to the place for bodies,* and is there consumed.

1683.text: Creator ! How shall the Mazdayaçnians bring fire back again to the dwelling in which the man died ?

1684.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : Nine nights shall the Mazdayaçnians wait in Winter, a month long in Summer.

1685.text: Afterwards the Mazdayaçnians may bring back the fire to the dwelling where the man died.

1686.text: Creator! If the Mazdayaçnians bring back fire to the house in which the man died ;

1687.text: Within nine nights, within a month,

1688.text: What is the punishment for it 1

1689.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : Let them inflict on their sinful bodies two hundred blows with the horse-goad, two hundred with the Çraoshô-charana.

1690.text: For one month, two months, three months, four months, five months, six months, seven, eight, nine, or ten months ;

1691.text: Then the woman is delivered, without a child, of something lifeless :

1693.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : (They shall bring it) to the purest place which is in this Mazdayaçnian dwelling,15

1695.text: Where the cattle and the beasts of burden go about the roads least,

1696.text: And the fire of Ahura-Mazda, the Bërëçma which is bound in holiness, and the pure man.

1697.text: Creator ! How far from the fire, how far from water, how far from the Bërëçma bound in holineas, and the pure man?

1698.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda: Thirtyt † steps from the fire, thirty steps from the water, thirty steps from the Bëreçma.

1699.text: Then shall the Mazdayaçnians make a raised place on the earth ;

1700.text: The Mazdayaçnians shall bring thither (the same), with food and with clothes shall the Mazdayaçnians bring them.

1701.text: Creator ! What food shall this woman first eat ?

1702.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : Ashes mixed with cow’s urine,

1703.text: Three drops, or six, or nine.

1704.text: (Thereby) they sprinkle the Dakhmas, which are within the fruitful child-bearing women.

1705.text: Then they may enjoy the warm milk of mares, cows, sheep, and goats,

1707.text: Cooked meat without water, pure corn without water, and wine without water.

1708.text: Creator ! How long shall they (who have been confined) wait, how long must they wait before they enjoy flesh, corn, and wine ?

1709.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda: Three nights shall they wait, three nights must they wait before they enjoy meat, corn, and wine.

1710.text: After three nights let them wash the naked body of (the child-bearing woman)* with cow’s urine and water, at nine holes,17 then is she clean.

1711.text: Creator ! How long shall they (who have borne children) wait, how long must they wait after the three nights before they return to the place, to food, and to clothing, with the other Mazdayaçnians ?

1712.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : Nine nights shall they wait, nine nights must they wait after the three nights before they return again to the place, the food, and the clothes, with the other Mazdayaçnians ?

1713.text: After nine nights they may wash their naked bodies † with cow’s urine and water, then are they clean.

1714.text: Creator! When are these clothes, after cleaning and washing them again, united [with other clothing] ‡

1715.text: For the Zaota, the Hâvanan, the Âtarëvakhsa, the Fra-bërëta, the Âberet, the Âçnâtâ, the Raêthwiskara, the Çraoshâ-varëza,18 the priests, the warriors, and the husbandmen ?

1716.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda: These clothes are not again united (i.e. to be used) after cleansing and washing ;

1717.text: By the Zaota, the Hâvanan, the Âtarëvakhsa, the Frabërëta, the Âberet, the Âçnâtâ, the Raêthwiskara, the Çraoshâ-varëza, the priests, the warriors, and the husbandmen.

1718.text: If a woman is suifering menstruation in this Mazda-yaçnian dwelling ;

1719.text: Or if a limb is broken, or the house is stained in consequence of a wound ;19

1720.text: Then this is the bed for it, this is the covering with which they cover.

1721.text: Until she brings out her hand with prayer and praise.*20

1722.text: For Ahura-Mazda does not throw away even things of the smallest value ;

1723.text: Not of the value of a thread ; not even so much in value :

1724.text: As a single reel throws off in quantity.

1725.text: If the Mazdayaçnians throw on a dead body21

1726.text: As much as a reel yields in quantity,

1727.text: Then are they not pure in life, and after death they taie no share in Paradise.

1728.text: Thy fill up the place which is appointed for the wicked,

1729.text: The dark, which comes from darkness.

1731.text: This place ye make, ye who are wicked, through your own deeds and your own law; the worst of places.

1732.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : A year long, 0 pure Zara-thustra! shall the land remain uncultivated on which dogs and men die.

1733.text: The Mazdayaçnians shall not till this land ; they shall not pour water on it within a year when dogs or men die upon it.

1734.text: After their desire shall the Mazdayaçnians till the other land ; after their desire shall they pour water on it.

1735.text: If the Mazdayaçnians till this land ; if they pour water on it when dogs or men die thereupon, within a year:

1736.text: Then these Mazdayaçnians commit the sin of burying the dead with respect to the water, to the earth, to the trees.

1737.text: Creator! If the Mazdayaçnians till the land upon which men and dogs have died ; if they pour water on it within a year ;

1738.text: What is the punishment for this ?

1739.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda: Let them strike their sinful bodies two hundred blows with the horse-goad, two hundred with the Çraôsho-charana.

1740.text: Creator! If the Mazdayaçnians wish to water the land for irrigation, for cultivation, for digging up ;

1742.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : These Mazdayaçnians shall look about on the earth for the bones, hair, nails, impurity, and flowing of blood.

1743.text: Creator! If they do not look about for bones, hair, nails, impurity, and flowing of blood ;

1744.text: What is the punishment for this ?

1745.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda: Let them strike their sin ful bodies two hundred blows with the horse-goad, two hundred with the Çraosho-charana.

1746.text: Creator! He who throws away the bone of a dead dog or a dead man, were it only so large as the top joint of the little finger,

1747.text: And there melts out1 upon it (‘the earth) grease and marrow ;

1748.text: What is the punishment for this?

1749.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : Strike thirty strokes with

1750.text: Creator! He who throws away the bone of a dead dog or a dead man,

1751.text: As large as the top joint of the middle finger:

1752.text: If grease or marrow run out there ;

1753.text: What is the punishment for this ?

1754.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda: Let them strike fifty strokes with the horse-goad, fifty with the Çraoshô-charana.

1755.text: Creator ! He who throws away the bone of a dead dog or a dead man,

1756.text: As large as the top joint of the largest finger :

1757.text: If grease or marrow runs out there ;

1758.text: What is the punishment for this?

1759.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : Let them strike seventy blows with the horse-goad, seventy with the Çraoshô-charana.

1760.text: Creator! He who throws away the bone of a dead dog or a dead man,

1761.text: Of the length of a finger, the size of a rib :

1762.text: And grease or marrow runs out there ;

1763.text: What is the punishment for this 1

1764.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : Let them strike ninety blows with the horse-goad, ninety with the Çraŏshô-charana.

1765.text: Creator ! He who throws away the bone of a dead dog or a dead man,

1766.text: As long as two fingers, as large as two ribs:

1767.text: If grease or marrow runs out there;

1768.text: What is the punishment for this ?

1769.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : Let them strike his sinful body two hundred blows with the horse-goad, two hundred with the Çraŏshô-charana.

1770.text: Of the length of an arm, of the size of a hip:*

1771.text: If there runs out there grease or marrow,

1772.text: What is the punishment for this?

1773.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda: Let them strike four hundred strokes with the horse-goad, four hundred with the Çraŏshô-charana.

1774.text: Creator ! He who throws away the bone of a dead dog or a dead man,

1775.text: As big as the head of a man :

1776.text: It marrow or grease runs out. there;

1777.text: What is the punishment for this?

1778.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda: Let them strike six hun-dred blows with the horse-goad, sis hundred with the Çraŏshô-charana.

1779.text: Creator ! He who throws away the whole body of a dead dog or a dead man,

1780.text: And grease or marrow runs out there ;

1781.text: What is the punishment for this ?

1782.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : Strike a thousand blows with the horse-goad, a thousand with the Çraŏsbô-eharana.2

1783.text: Creator ! If the Mazdayaçnians, [whilst] going a-foot, running, riding, or driving, come to a dead body floating in the water :

1785.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : Laying aside their shoes, pulling off their clothes,

1787.text: They shall go in, they shall drag the dead out of the water, 0 Zarathustra.

1788.text: They shall [go] into the water as far as the feet, as far as the knee, as far as the middle of the body, as far as the height of a man.

1789.text: Until they reach the dead body.

1790.text: Creator! If these dead bodies are stinking and rotten ;

1792.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : As much as they can grasp of it with both hands, so much shall they drag out of the water and lay it on the dry ground.

1793.text: By throwing about bones, hair, nails,3 impurities, and blood, one does not defile the water.

1794.text: Creator ! Upon how much of the water which is in the pool does the Drukhs Nacus settle with dissolution, rottenness, and defilement.

1795.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda; Sis paces in all four directions ;

1796.text: So far is the water impure, and not to be used until the corpse is taken away.

1797.text: From this water they shall drain the half, the third, the fourth, or the fifth,

1798.text: According as they can or can not.

1799.text: Afterwards, when the corpse has been brought out, when [part of] the water has been drained off, this water is pure, and may be used after their desire by cattle and men, just as before.

1800.text: Creator! Upon how much of well-water4 which springs up does the Drukhs Naçus place himself with dissolution, rottenness, and tilth ?

1801.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : So long is this water impure and not to be used until the corpse is taken out.

1802.text: Creator ! Upon how much of snow and hail-water does this Drnkhs Nacus place himself with dissolution, rottenness, and filth?

1803.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : Three paces in all four quarters ;

1804.text: So far is this water impure and not to be used, until the corpse is taken out.

1805.text: They shall take out the corpse and lay [it] on the dry land.

1806.text: When the corpses are taken out, when the water is thawed, then is this water pure, and may be used according to their desire by men and cattle, just as before.

1807.text: Creator! Upon how much of running water does the Drukhs Naçus settle?

1808.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda: Three paces backwards, three paces forwards, six paces on the sides ;

1809.text: So far is the water impure and not to be used, until the dead body is taken out.

1810.text: They shall take the dead body out of the water and lay it on dry land.

1811.text: When the corpses have been taken out, and when it has rained on it three times, then this water is pure, and may be used according to their desire by cattle and men, just as before.

1812.text: Creator ! When is the Haöma pure which has been brought to a dead dog or man, 0 pure Ahura-Mazda ?

1813.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : It is pure, 0 pure Zara-thustra !

1814.text: The prepared Haŏma has neither dissolution nor death ;

1815.text: Not even when it is brought to a dead body.

1816.text: Only that which is not prepared, as much as four fingers long,

1817.text: This shall they lay on the ground, in the midst of the dwelling,

1818.text: Until a year is gone by.

1819.text: After the expiration of a year, it can be used according to [his] desire by the pure man, just as before.

1820.text: Creator! Where shall we carry the bodies of the dead, 0 Ahura-Mazda ! where shall we lay them down ?

1821.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda: On the highest place, 0 holy Zarathustra!

1822.text: Where they are most perceived by carnivorous dogs and birds.

1823.text: The Mazdayaçnians shall fasten these dead bodies by their own feet and hair,*

1825.text: If not, then will the carnivorous dogs and birds carry away [some] of the bones to the water, and to the trees.

1826.text: Creator! If they do not fasten them, and the carnivorous dogs and birds take some of the bones to the water and the trees;

1827.text: What is the punishment for this?

1828.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : Strike their sinful bodies two hundred strokes with the horse-goad, two hundred with the Çraŏshô-charana.

1829.text: Creator ! Where shall we bring the carcases5 of the dead, 0 Ahura-Mazda ! where shall we lay them down ?

1830.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : They shall turn them upwards [or, place them up high],

1831.text: Above the dogs, above the panthers, above the wolves,‡6

1832.text: So that they cannot be rained upon from above by the rain.

1833.text: If the Mazdayaçnians can, they shall lay them on stone, mortar, or carpet;7

1834.text: If they cannot, then they shall lay them down on the earth, on their own bed, and their own mat, exposed to the light, looking towards the Sun.

1835.text: When does the Drukhs Naçus rush to the dead men?

1836.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : immediately after death, 0 holy Zarathustra! consciousness* departs.

1837.text: The Drukhs Naçus rushes hither from the region of the North, in the form of a fly, pernicious when she comes bringing immense filth from her anus, as (do) the most hideous of the Khrafetras.1

1838.text: Creator! When these (corpses) have been slain by dogs, wolves, sorcerers, by wounds,† by falls,2 by men, by violence, by anguish, ‡ after how long a time does Drukhs Naçus arrive?

1839.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : After the next division of the day.

1840.text: Creator! If several men all together in the same place, or on the same bed and the same mat.

1841.text: If two other persons are there opposite one,

1842.text: Or five, or fifty, or a hundred, together with [their] wives. v§

1843.text: Then one of these men dies : upon how many of the men does the Drukhs Naçus settle with corruption, rottenness, and impurity ?

1844.text: Then answered Ahnra-Mazda : If it is a priest, 0 holy Zarathustra! the Drukhs Naçus rushes up;||

1845.text: If he settles on the eleventh, he defiles the tenth,

1846.text: If it is a soldier, then rushes up the Drukhs Naçus, 0 holy Zarathustra !

1847.text: If he settles on the tenth, he defiles the ninth.

1848.text: If it is an husbandman, then the Drukhs Naçus flies up, 0 holy Zarathustra !

1849.text: If he settles on the ninth, he defiles the eighth.

1850.text: If it is a dog belonging to the cattle, then the Drukhs Naçus flies up, 0 holy Zarathustra!

1851.text: If he settles on the eighth, he defiles the seventh.

1852.text: If it is a house-dog, then the Drukhs Naçus flies up, 0 holy Zarathustra !

1853.text: If he settles on the seventh, he defiles the sixth.

1854.text: Then if it is a blood-hound the Drukhs Naçus rushes up, 0 holy Zarathustra !

1855.text: If he settles on the sixth, he defiles the fifth.

1856.text: If it is a young dog, then the Drukhs Naçus flies up, 0 holy Zarathustra !

1857.text: If he settles on the fifth, he defiles the fourth.

1858.text: This one has a bed or a mat with which they cover him ;3

1859.text: Creator ! Upon how many of these—the bed and the mat* —doe3 the Drukhs Naçus settle ?

1860.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : Up on the top of this bed,4 on the out-most covering thereof, the Drukhs Naçus settles with corruption, rottenness, and impurity.

1861.text: Creator! How do these garments become pure again, 0 pure Ahura-Mazda ! which have been placed on the body of a dead dog or a dead man ?

1862.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : They become pure, 0 pure Zarathustra!

1864.text: If they are † stained with matter, with dirt, or with vomit, ‡

1865.text: Then the Mazdayaçnians shall cut these garments in pieces and bury them.

1866.text: If they are not stained with matter, dirt, or vomit,

1867.text: Then shall the Mazdayaçnians wash these garments with cow’s urine.

1868.text: If they [the garments] consist of hair, § 5 then they shall wash them three times with cow’s urine, rub them three time3 with earth, wash them three times with water, air them three months at the window of the house.

1869.text: If they are woven, ||6 they shall wash them six times with cow’s urine, rub them six times with earth, wash them six times with water, air them six months at the window of the dwelling.

1870.text: The water which is called, Ardvî-cura, 0 holy Zarathustra ! purifies my waters; ¶

1872.text: This (purifies) the fruit of the body ** of women;

1874.text: Creator! how are these garments again suitable after the purification and the washing ;

1875.text: For the Zŏatâ, for Havana, for the Atarëvakhs, the Fra-beretaa, the Âberet, the Âçnâtâ, the Raéthwiskara, the Çraoshâ-vareza, for the priests, the soldiers, and the husbandmen ?8

1876.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : These garments are not serviceable again after the purification and washing,

1877.text: Not for the Zŏatâ, not for the Hâvanan, not for the Atarevakhs, not for the Fraberera, not for the Abërët, not for the Âçnâtà, not for the Raêthwiskara, not for the Çraoshâ-varëza, not for the priest, not for the warrior, not for the husbandman.

1878.text: If a woman in a Mazdayaçnian dwelling is afflicted with menstruation ;

1879.text: Or if a limb has been broken and a wound stains the house ;

1880.text: Until she brings out her hands in praise and prayer.

1881.text: For Ahura-Mazda does not throw away pieces of garments 9

1882.text: Not the size of a thread, not even so much in size

1883.text: AS a reel* throws off according to proportion.

1884.text: If the Mazdayaçnians throw upon a dead body as much

1885.text: As a reel yields in quantity,

1886.text: Then they are not pure in life, and after death they receive no share in Paradise ;

1887.text: They fill the place which is appointed for the wicked ;

1888.text: The dark which cornea from darkness ;

1890.text: This place make ye, you who are evil by your deeds and your law, the most hateful place.

1891.text: Creator ! When are those men pure, 0 pure Ahura-Mazda I who have eaten of the body of a dead dog or a dead man?

1892.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : They are unclean, 0 holy Zarathustra !

1893.text: These men are made for the holes.10

1894.text: Let them bring these men away from the white eye ;11

1895.text: On their nails springs the Drukhs Naçus ;

1896.text: Hereafter they are unclean for ever.

1897.text: Creator ! How do those men become clean, 0 pure Ahura-Mazda ! who bring a corpse with dirt to the water or the fire with uncleanness ?12

1898.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : They are unclean, 0 pure Zarathustra !

1899.text: The wicked who have defilied themselves with corpses are the most helpful to the dog Madhakha ;

1900.text: They are most helpful to the drought which destroys the pasture, those who have defiled themselves with corpses;

1901.text: They are most helpful to the winter which the Daevas have created, which kills the dogs, is full of snow, the slowly-passing, wounding, evil, wicked-knowing, those who have defiled themselves with corpses ;13

1902.text: The Drukhs Naçus springs on their nails,

1903.text: Then are they unclean for ever.

1904.text: Creator ! When is the wood pure, 0 pure Ahura-Mazda ! which has been brought to the body of a dead dog or man 1

1905.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : It is clean, 0 pure Zara-thustra !

1907.text: If the body has not yet been gnawed by carnivorous dogs or birds,

1908.text: Then they shall (of this wood), of the length of a Vitasti if it is dry, of the length of a Frârathni14 if it is green,

1909.text: Lay down on the earth in four directions ; they shall sprinkle it once with water, then it is pure.

1910.text: If the body has already been gnawed by carnivorous dogs and birds,

1911.text: Then shall they the length of a Frârâthni if dry, the length of a Frabazu if green,

1912.text: Lay down on the earth in all four directions ; they shall sprinkle it once with water, then it is pure.

1913.text: Thus shall they the dry wood, thus the green,

1914.text: Thus the hard, thus the soft, lay down on the earth in all four directions; they shall sprinkle it with water, then is it pure.15

1915.text: Creator ! How do corn and fodder become pure, O pure Ahura-Mazda! which have been brought to the body of a dead dog or man ?

1916.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : They become pure, 0 pure Zarathustra !

1918.text: If the corpse has not been gnawed by carnivorous dogs or birds,

1919.text: Then the length of a Frârâthni if dry, the length of a Frabazu if green, shall they

1920.text: Lay down upon the earth towards all four quarters; they shall sprinkle it with water, then it is pure.

1921.text: But if the body has already been gnawed by carnivorous dogs and birds,

1922.text: Then the length of a Frabazu if dry, the length of a Vibazu if green, shall they

1923.text: Lay down upon the earth in all four directions ; they shall sprinkle it with water, then is it pure.

1924.text: So much of dry, so much of green ;

1925.text: So much of the cultivated, so much of the uncultivated ; so much of the reaped, so much of the unreaped produce ; so much of those with husks, so much of those without husks; much of the mixed fruits, shall they lay down in the earth in all four directions, and sprinkle them once with water, then are they pure.16

1926.text: Creator! When the Mazdayaçnians wish to make themselves physicians,

1927.text: Whom shall they first cure, the Daevayaenians* or the Mazdayaçnians ?

1928.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : They shall make trial of healing on the Daevayaçuians before the Mazdayaçnians.

1929.text: If he begins to cut a Daevayaçnian for the first time and he dies ; if he begins to cut a Daevayaçnian for the second time and he dies ; if he cuts a Daevayaçnian for a third time and he dies,

1930.text: Then is he incapable for ever.

1931.text: The Mazdayaçnians shall not try (consult) him afterwards ; he shall not cut the Mazdayaçnians ; he shall not wound by cutting.

1932.text: If the Mazdayaçnians afterwards try him, if he cuts the Mazdayaçnians, if he wounds them by cutting-,

1933.text: Then shall he atone for the wound of the wounded (man) with the punishment of the Baŏdho-varsta.17

1934.text: If he begins to cut a Daevayaçnian for the first time and he recovers ; if he cuts a Daevayaçnian for the second time and he recovers; if he cuts a Daevayaçnian for the third time and he recovers,

1935.text: Then is he capable for ever.

1936.text: According to (their) wish shall the Mazdayaçnians afterwards make trial of him; ho shall cut the Mazdayçnians as he pleases ; he shall heal them by cutting at his will.

1937.text: Let him cure the master of a house for the value of a small beast of burden.

1938.text: Let him cure the ruler of a clan for the value of a middle-sized beast of burden.

1939.text: Let him cure the chief of a tribe for the value of a large beast of burden.

1940.text: Let him cure the ruler of a territory for the value of a chariot with four oxen.

1941.text: If he first cures the mistress of a house, then a female ass is his reward.

1942.text: if he cures the wife of the chief of a clan, then a cow is his reward.

1943.text: If he cures the wife of the chief of a tribe, then a mare is his reward.

1944.text: If he cures the wife of the ruler of a district, then a female camel is his reward.

1945.text: Let him cure a boy from the village for the price of a large beaat of burden.

1946.text: Let him cure a large beast of burden for the price of a middle-sized beast of burden.

1947.text: Let him cure a middle-sized beast of burden for the price of a small beast of burden.

1948.text: Let him cure a small beast of burden for the price of small animals, and small animals for the price of food.

1949.text: When many physicians come together, 0 holy Zara-thustra !

1950.text: Physicians with knives, physicians with herbs, physicians with holy sayings [incantations ?] ;

1951.text: Then is it the most healing among physicians who use the Manthra-Çpenta as a remedy.

1952.text: Creator ! how lung does a dead man lie on the earth exposed to the light, the sun beholding him, and the earth is (pure) ?

1953.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : A year long, 0 pure Zara-thustra ! does the dead man lie on the earth exposed to the light, the sun beholding him, and the land is (pure).

1954.text: Creator ! How long can the body of a man be buried in the earth until the earth becomes pure?

1955.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda: Fifty years, 0 holy Zara-thustra ! must the body of a man remain buried in the earth before the earth is pure.

1956.text: Creator ! How long can the bodies of men be laid on the Dakhmas until the earth is pure ?

1957.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : (It is not pure), 0 holy Zarathustra! before this dust is amalgamated (with the earth).

1958.text: Exhort, 0 holy Zarathustra ! all men in the corporeal world to destroy these Dakhmas.†19

1959.text: He who destroys so much of these Dakhmas as is equal to his own body,

1960.text: He has confessed (his sins) in thoughts, and words, and deeds.

1961.text: He has atoned with regard to thoughts, words, and deeds;

1962.text: For the two heavenly powers will not begin a strife against this man,20

1964.text: They praise him, 0 Zarathustra! stars, moon, and sun.

1965.text: I praise him, I, the Creator Ahura-Mazda.

1966.text: “ Hail to thee, 0 man ! thou who art come from the perishable places to the imperishable.” 21

1967.text: Creator ! Where are the Daevas, where the worshippers of the Daevas, where is the flocking together of the Daevas, where the assembling of the Daevas, where do the Daevas come together to the slaying of fifty for the slayers of a hundred, to the slaughter of a hundred for those who slay a thousand, to tha slaughter of a thousand for those who slay ten thousand, to the slaughter of ten thousand for those who slay innumerable ones.22

1968.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : In these Dakhmas which are raised up on the earth, where they lay dead men, 0 holy Zarathu3tra 23

1969.text: There are the Daevas, there the Daeva-worshippers, there is the flocking together of the Daevas, there the assembling of the Daevas, there the coming together of the Daevas to the slaying of fifty for the slayers of a hundred, to the slaughter of a hundred for those who slay a thousand, to the slaughter of a thousand for those who slay ten thousand, to the slaughter of ten thousand for those who slay a countless (number).

1970.text: Similarly, 0 holy Zarathustra ! do the Daevas collect together at these Dakhmas and copulate ;

1971.text: As you, ye who are men in this corporeal world, make ready cooked food and eat cooked flesh.24

1972.text: Therefore take heed, ye men, and consider what ye eat ;25

1973.text: For that is the joy of the Daevas,

1975.text: For in these Dakhmas there are together dissolution, sickness, fever, uncleanness, cold fever, shivering, and old remains of hair.*26

1976.text: In these Dakhmas the men are the deadliest.

1978.text: They envy who have little understanding, not those who have much.

1979.text: The third part of this corruption Jannaya keeps

1980.text: With the loins, the hands, and Gaèçus.

1981.text: One, two, three, four, five, sis, seven, eight, nine, or ten months ;

1982.text: If then this woman lies in with a lifeless child,

1985.text: Where least there go about on the ways the cattle, the beasts of burden, the fire of Ahura-Mazda, the Beréçma bound together in holiness, and the pure man.

1986.text: Creator ! How far from the fire, how far from water, how far from the Bërëçma which is bound up, how far from the pure man 1

1987.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : Thirty steps from fire, thirty steps from water, thirty steps from the Bĕrĕçma bound together, thirty steps from pure men.

1988.text: The Mazdayaçnians shall make a raised place on the earth.

1989.text: Afterwards the Mazdayaçnians shall bring her here with food ; the Mazdayaçnians shall bring her here with clothes.

1990.text: Creator ! What food shall this woman first eat ?

1991.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : Ashes mixed with cow’s urine,

1992.text: Three drops, six drops, or nine.

1993.text: She sprinkles (with this) the Dakhmas which are inside the fruitful child-bearing women,

1994.text: Then let her drink warm milk of mares, cows, sheep, or beasts of burden ;

1996.text: Let her have cooked meat without water, pure vegetables without water, wine without water.

1997.text: Creator ! How long must she wait, how long must one wait until she may have meat, vegetables, and wine ?

1998.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : Three nights shall she wait, three nights must one wait until she may have meat, vegetables, and wine.

1999.text: After three nights let her wash her naked body with the urine of a cow and with water by nine holes, then is she clean.

2000.text: Creator ! But if a fever ensues whilst her body is unclean ;28

2001.text: If two bad sicknesses befall her; hunger and thirst;29

2003.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda: She shall drink,

2004.text: For that is her greatest advantage, if she purifies her vital powers.

2005.text: With the exception of any of the holy prayers known to the pure and pious men (i.e. the advantage of such prayers is greater than that which follows from purification) ;30

2006.text: But if she drinks the water with her hands,

2007.text: Then she brings punishment to you who are Mazdayaçnians.

2008.text: (The recitation of the Ratu and the Çraŏshâ-varza takes the punishment away.)

2010.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : As a punishment for her sinful body, let them strike two hundred blows with the horse-goad, two hundred with the Çraŏshô-charana.

2011.text: Creator ! How do the vessels out of which one eats become clean which have been brought to the carcass of a dead dog or man ?

2012.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : They are clean, 0 pure Zarathustra !

2014.text: If they are of gold, wash them once with cow’s urine, lift them once up from the earth, wash them once with water, then are they clean.

2015.text: If they are of silver, wash them six times* with cow’s urine, lift them up from the earth six times, wash them six times with water, then are they clean.

2016.text: If they are of earth, wood, or lead, then are they unclean for ever.31

2017.text: Creator ! How are the beasts pure which have eaten of the carcass of a dead dog or man ?

2018.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda: They are pure, 0 Zarathustra !

2019.text: Only let them not bring cheese (from them) as an offering, or flesh as an offering for the Bĕrĕçma within a year :

2020.text: After a year can they be used according to their wish by pure men, just as before.

2021.text: Who is that, 0 pure Ahura-Mazda ! who, thinking purity, wishing purity, nevertheless ruins purity ; who thinks purity, wishes purity, and nevertheless furthers the Drujas ?

2022.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda: He it is, 0 pure Zarathustra ! who, meditating purity, wishing purity, (yet) ruins purity ; who thinks purity, wishes purity, and nevertheless furthers the Drujas ;

2023.text: Who carries out water in which the unclcanne33 of a carcass is contained, without purification ;

2024.text: Who carries out water in the darkness of night without purification.32

2025.text: A dog or a man should die :

2027.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : They shall seek out a Dakhma, and shall make it ready.

2028.text: If they perceive that the body is fit to be carried,

2029.text: They shall bring it (to the dwelling) and leave the dwelling there ; †

2030.text: They shall fumigate the dwelling with Urvaçna, Vôhu-gaŏna, YÔhu-kërSti, Hadhâ-naêpata, ‡ and all kinds of sweet-smelling trees.

2031.text: If they pereeive that the dwelling is portable, §

2032.text: Then they shall bring the dwelling there, and shall leave the dead there ;2

2033.text: They shall fumigate the dwelling with Urvaçna, Vôhu-gaŏna, Vôhu-kĕrĕti, Hadhâ-naêpata, and all kinds of odoriferous trees.

2034.text: Creator! If in this Mazdayaçnian dwelling-place a dog or a man dies ;

2035.text: And it rains or snows, or a strong wind blows, or darkness has spread itself abroad, and hinders work and strength for this day:

2037.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : Where in this Mazdayaç-nian dwelling-place is the purest and the driest earth ;

2038.text: Where cattle, draught-beasts, || the fire of Ahura-Mazda, the Bĕrĕçma bound together in purity, and the pure man go least along the ways.

2039.text: Creator! How far from fire, how far from water, how far from the Bĕrĕçma bound together, how far from the pure men ?

2040.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda ; Thirty paces from the fire, thirty paces from the water, thirty pace3 from the Bĕrĕcma, and thirty ¶ paces from the pure men ;

2041.text: There shal the Mazdayaçnians dig a hole in this earth,3

2042.text: Half a foot deep in hard ground, half the height of a man in soft ground ;

2043.text: On the top of the same shall they bring the dust of bricks, stones, or dry earth ;

2044.text: Thus shall they lay down the soulless body two nights, three nights, or a month long,

2045.text: Until the birds fly away, the trees grow up, the evil ones* hasten away, and the wind dries the earth.

2046.text: Then when the birds fly away, the trees grow up, the evil ones hasten away, and the winds dry the earth;4

2047.text: Then shall the Mazdayaçnians cut down † that dwelling, ‡

2048.text: Two men shall take him (the dead) up—pure and strong ones—

2049.text: .Naked and without clothes (lying), on bricks, stone, or mortar, away to the Kata.5

2050.text: They shall lay him down on the earth,

2051.text: Where most carnivorous dogs and birds best perceive him.§

2052.text: There shall those who bear the dead sit themselves down, there paces from the dead.

2053.text: Then let the pure Ratu speak to the Mazdayaçniana : “ Mazdayaçnians ! “

2054.text: “ Bring hither the urine with which those who have carried the dead shall wash their hair and their bodies.”

2055.text: Creator! How shall this urine be, 0 pure Ahura-Mazda,

2056.text: With which those who have carried the dead shall wash their bair and their bodies 1

2057.text: Shall it be of cattle,|| of beasts of burden, of men, or of women ?

2058.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : Of cattle,¶ of beasts of burden, not of men, and not of women.

2059.text: With the exception of two—the male and female relations.**

2060.text: These shall make the urine wherewith those who have carried the corpse shall wash their hair and their bodies.

2061.text: Creator ! When they carry dead dogs and dead men along the road,

2062.text: How shall the cattle, the draught-beasts, men and women, the fire, the son of Ahura-Mazda, and the Bĕrĕçma, which is bound in holiness, go on these ways ?

2063.text: Then answered Ahura-Mazda : The cattle and the beasts of burden shall not go on these ways, not the men and women, not the fire, the son of Ahura-Mazda, and the Bĕrĕcma bound in holiness.

2064.text: A yellow dog with four eyes,* or a white one with yellow ears,6

2065.text: Shall they lead three times along this road.

2066.text: By this, 0 holy Zarathustra, by leading along a yellow dog with four eyes, or a white one with yellow ears,

2067.text: By this the Drukhs Naçus flies away to the Northern regions.

2068.text: If not, then let them lead a yellow dog with four eyes, or a white one with yellow ears, six times along this road, 0 holy Zarathustra ;

2069.text: For by this, 0 holy Zarathustra [namely], by leading about a yellow dog with four eyes, or a white one with yellow ears, the Drukhs Naçus flies away to the North regions.

2070.text: If not, let them lead a yellow dog with four eyes, or a white one with yellow ears, nine times along this road ;

2071.text: For thus, 0 holy Zarathustra, by leading about a yellow dog with four eyes, or a white one with yellow ears, the Drukhs Naçus runs to the Northern regions.7

2072.text: A priest shall first walk along this road, speaking the victorious words : Yathâ ahû vairyô.

2075.text: “ Whom Ahura-Mazda created for a Protector to me and those like me (i.e., my followers).”

2076.text: “ If the bad ones (Anra-mainyus) seek to harm me.”

2077.text: “ Besides thee, the Fire and Vôhu-manô, if I walk after Thy works, 0 Holy one (then help me), 0 Ahura !”

2078.text: “ Tell me this law by the Destur,”

2079.text: “ Which smites victoriously through Thy protection and teaching.”

2080.text: “ Make manifest to me in both places a Ratu for the law.”

2081.text: “ Then may Çraŏsha and Vôhu-manô come,”

2082.text: “ 0 Mazda ! May my wish be the wish of every one.”

2083.text: “Ahura-Mazda and Çpĕnta-ârmaiti defend us from our foes.”

2084.text: “I drive back the Daeva-Drukhs; I drive back that which proceeds from the Daevas ; I drive back what they have done and created.”

2085.text: “I drive away the Daevas: begone, 0 Drukhs! I drive away the Drukhs that he may rush to the North ; he shall not destroy the corporeal world of the pure.” †

2086.text: After their desire may the Mazdayaçnians then travel on these roads : cattle, beasts of burden, men and women, the fire the son of Ahura-Mazda, the Bĕrĕçma bound together in holiness.

2087.text: As they will may the Mazdayaçnians then prepare meat and wine in this dwelling ; it will be pure without spot as before.9
